Evaluation Criteria

What Gets an A? What Gets a D?

Assessment Overview

Component Weight What It Is
Weekly Research & Reflection 20% Your Notion portfolio + Slack contributions
Video Essay 20% 1-minute video on how climate change affects you
Final Reflective Essay 20% 750-word narrative that moves people to action
Visual Creation 20% Collage communicating your climate solution
Participation 20% In-class debates + tutorial engagement

Weekly Research & Reflection

What does ‚ÄúReflection‚Äù mean?

This isn‚Äôt just journaling. Each week you research (find facts, stories, sources) AND reflect (what does this mean for you? how does it change your thinking? what surprised you?). Your Notion portfolio should show both: the evidence you gathered AND your thinking about it.

Your weekly contributions are graded on three equally important criteria:

Verifiability

Can it be fact-checked?

Creativity

Is your spectacle compelling?

Conciseness

Did you say it efficiently?

Pillar 1: Verifiability (Can It Be Fact-Checked?)

This is non-negotiable. Every fact, statistic, and story must have a source.

Grade What It Looks Like
A Every claim has a credible source (academic papers, major news outlets, official reports). Sources are recent and relevant. You could defend this in a court of fact-checkers.
B Most claims sourced, sources are credible. One or two minor claims might lack citation but are easily verifiable.
C Some sources provided, but quality is inconsistent. Some claims come from questionable sources (random blogs, old data, biased outlets).
D Few or no sources. Claims are vague (‚Äústudies show‚Ä¶‚Äù) without specifics. Would fail a basic fact-check.
F Invented facts, fabricated statistics, or made-up stories. This is academic dishonesty.

Acceptable Sources

  • Academic journals, peer-reviewed papers
  • Major news outlets (Reuters, AP, BBC, NYT, SCMP, etc.)
  • Government reports, UN/IPCC data
  • Official company reports, press releases
  • Reputable NGOs (WHO, Greenpeace, WWF, etc.)

Unacceptable Sources

  • Random blogs, personal websites
  • Social media posts (unless citing the original source)
  • Wikipedia (use it to find sources, not as a source)
  • ‚ÄúI heard that‚Ä¶‚Äù or ‚ÄúEveryone knows‚Ä¶‚Äù
  • AI-generated ‚Äúfacts‚Äù (ChatGPT can hallucinate)

Pillar 2: Creativity (Is Your Spectacle Compelling?)

You‚Äôre not just reporting facts ‚Äî you‚Äôre crafting narratives that move people.

Grade What It Looks Like
A Your spectacle makes people feel something. Original framing that connects facts to human stakes. Memorable, quotable, emotionally resonant. Would work in a real campaign.
B Good attempt at emotional framing. The connection between fact and feeling is clear. Competent but not striking.
C Basic restatement of facts with some emotional language added. Feels formulaic. ‚ÄúAI is bad because it uses energy.‚Äù
D Just listing facts with no narrative craft. No attempt to make it memorable or emotional. Reads like a Wikipedia summary.
F No original thought. Copy-pasted from sources. Or: fabricated emotional stories (see Verifiability).

The Transformation Test

Weak (D): ‚ÄúAI data centers consume 415 TWh of electricity annually.‚Äù

Better (C): ‚ÄúAI data centers use a huge amount of electricity ‚Äî more than many countries.‚Äù

Good (B): ‚ÄúAI data centers consume more electricity than Pakistan, a country of 240 million people.‚Äù (Source: IEA 2024)

Excellent (A): ‚ÄúTraining one large AI model emits as much carbon as five cars over their entire lifetimes. And we‚Äôre building thousands of them ‚Äî while telling kids to recycle.‚Äù (Source: Strubell et al. 2019)

Real example of fact-checking failure

An earlier draft of this page claimed ‚Äúone ChatGPT query powers a Pakistani home for a week.‚Äù That sounded dramatic ‚Äî but the math doesn‚Äôt check out (a query uses ~0.01 kWh; a home uses ~50+ kWh/week). We caught it because we applied the same test we‚Äôre teaching you. Always verify before you amplify.

Pillar 3: Conciseness (Did You Say It Efficiently?)

Longer is not better. Verbose writing signals unclear thinking.

Grade What It Looks Like
A Every word earns its place. Dense with insight, zero filler. Clear, punchy, memorable.
B Mostly efficient. Some sentences could be tightened but overall well-edited.
C Noticeable padding. Repetitive points. Could cut 30% without losing meaning.
D Rambling, unfocused. Buries good points in walls of text. Reader loses interest.
F Incoherent or clearly padded to meet a word count that doesn‚Äôt exist.

Word Count Guidelines

Component Target Maximum
Weekly Notion entry 300-500 words 750 words
Slack post 100-150 words 200 words
Spectacle draft 1-2 sentences 3 sentences
Final essay 600-750 words 750 words (hard cap)

Penalty for excessive length: If you exceed the maximum by more than 20%, you lose one grade step (e.g., A ‚Üí A-, B+ ‚Üí B).

Weekly Contribution Examples

Example A: Excellent

**[PRO CLIMATE]**

üìä **My Fact:**
Training GPT-4 emitted an estimated 552 tons of CO‚ÇÇ ‚Äî equivalent to
driving a car around Earth 22 times.
Source: Strubell et al., 2019 (updated estimates via MIT Tech Review 2023)

üìñ **My Story:**
In 2024, a Rice University engineering student took their own life.
Friends reported overwhelming pressure from AI replacing entry-level jobs
‚Äî the very jobs students train years to get.
Source: Houston Chronicle, March 2024

üí• **My Spectacle:**
"You're training for jobs that won't exist by graduation. And every time
you cheer for AI progress, you're cheering for your own obsolescence ‚Äî
powered by coal plants that give kids asthma."

üîó Full research: [Notion link]

Why this is an A: - Facts are specific, sourced, verifiable - Story is real, documented, emotionally resonant - Spectacle connects personal stakes (your job) to systemic harm (coal plants) - Concise ‚Äî says a lot in few words

Example B: Good

**[PRO CLIMATE]**

üìä **My Fact:**
AI data centers are projected to use 945 TWh by 2030, more than
doubling from 2024 levels.
Source: IEA Energy and AI Report 2024

üìñ **My Story:**
Microsoft pledged to be carbon negative by 2030, but their emissions
increased 29% in 2023, largely due to AI infrastructure expansion.
Source: Microsoft Sustainability Report 2024

üí• **My Spectacle:**
"Tech companies promise green AI while their emissions skyrocket.
The pledge is marketing; the coal plant is real."

üîó Full research: [Notion link]

Why this is a B: - Well-sourced, verifiable facts - Story is corporate-level (less personal resonance) - Spectacle is clear but less emotionally punchy than an A

Example C: Adequate

**[PRO CLIMATE]**

üìä **My Fact:**
AI uses a lot of energy and this is growing fast.
Source: Various news articles

üìñ **My Story:**
Many tech workers are worried about AI taking their jobs and
causing environmental problems.

üí• **My Spectacle:**
"AI is bad for the environment and we should be concerned about it."

üîó Full research: [Notion link]

Why this is a C: - Fact is vague, source is ‚Äúvarious‚Äù - Story is generic, no specific case - Spectacle is a bland statement, not emotionally compelling - Would pass a fact-check but doesn‚Äôt demonstrate mastery

Example D: Poor

**[PRO CLIMATE]**

üìä **My Fact:**
Studies show AI is destroying the planet.

üìñ **My Story:**
I heard that lots of people are dying because of AI pollution.

üí• **My Spectacle:**
AI is killing us all and nobody cares.

üîó Full research: None

Why this is a D: - No sources - ‚ÄúStudies show‚Äù and ‚ÄúI heard‚Äù are red flags - Story is unverifiable - Spectacle is hyperbolic without factual backing - Would fail a fact-check

Example F: Failing

**[PRO CLIMATE]**

üìä **My Fact:**
AI has already killed 50,000 people from pollution-related deaths
in the US alone.

üìñ **My Story:**
There was a village in China where everyone died because a data
center poisoned their water supply.

üí• **My Spectacle:**
"Big Tech is literally committing genocide and the government is
covering it up."

üîó Full research: None needed, it's obvious

Why this is an F: - Fabricated statistics - Invented story - Inflammatory claims without evidence - This is misinformation, not persuasion - Academic integrity violation

Video Essay (20%)

A 1-minute video using your own voice, images, and text on how climate change affects you personally.

Criterion What We‚Äôre Looking For
Personal Connection It‚Äôs about you ‚Äî your life, your community, your future. Not abstract facts.
Narrative Arc Has a beginning, middle, end. Takes the viewer somewhere.
Production Quality Clear audio, readable text, intentional visuals. Doesn‚Äôt need to be fancy ‚Äî needs to be watchable.
Fact-Grounded Any claims you make should be verifiable (same rules as weekly work).

Final Reflective Essay (20%)

A 750-word narrative that synthesizes what you‚Äôve learned and advocates for a climate solution that could move people to action.

Criterion What We‚Äôre Looking For
Synthesis Draws on arguments and evidence from across the semester ‚Äî not just one week.
Persuasive Narrative Tells a story, not a report. Makes the reader feel something.
Actionable Points toward something people can actually do. Not despair ‚Äî direction.
Polished Writing Clear, concise, well-structured. Every sentence earns its place.

Visual Creation (20%)

A collage or visual piece that communicates your climate solution alongside your final essay.

Criterion What We‚Äôre Looking For
Coherence with Essay The visual and written work tell the same story in different languages.
Visual Impact Grabs attention. Would work on a gallery wall or protest sign.
Intentional Choices Colors, composition, imagery ‚Äî all deliberate, all meaningful.
Craft Shows effort and care. Medium doesn‚Äôt matter (digital, collage, illustration) ‚Äî execution does.

The Golden Rule

Everything must be fact-checkable.

You're learning to persuade with real stories, not to deceive with fake ones.
The power of a spectacle comes from its truth ‚Äî not from invention.

Quick Self-Check Before Submitting

Ask yourself:

  1. ‚úÖ Can someone Google my facts and find them true?
  2. ‚úÖ Did I cite specific, credible sources?
  3. ‚úÖ Is my story about real people/events, not hypotheticals?
  4. ‚úÖ Does my spectacle make people feel something?
  5. ‚úÖ Could I cut 20% without losing meaning?
  6. ‚úÖ Would I be comfortable defending this in a debate?

If you answered ‚Äúno‚Äù to any of these, revise before submitting.

Questions?

Unclear about whether something counts as a credible source? Ask in #general on Slack or come to office hours. Better to check than to lose marks.
